text.title: Lasithi Plateau
text.author: Wikivoyage community (see URL)
text.head: Lasithi Plateau
text.p: Lasithi Plateau is a plateau with avg. altitude 820m in Crete (Greece).
text.head: Understand
text.p: A rewarding day trip by car from Malia. Hotels in the area are overpriced.

Lasithi Plateau, a mountainous municipality, is the westernmost of the 4 municipalities in Lasithi Prefecture. In the south of Lasithi Plateau is the . This small plateau is used for shepherding. It lacks permanent residents but does have a Byzantine church dedicated to the Holy Spirit.

The residents of Lasithi Plateau are still influenced by conservative concepts and by the precepts of the Orthodox Church. Their attitude toward foreign visitors can vary greatly but is never disrespectful.
text.head: Talk
text.p: The spoken language is the Cretan idiom of Greek, with additional languages spoken by young people, owners and staff of hotels, tavernas and museums.

text.head: Get in
text.p: The plateau is accessible through a two paved and some unpaved roads climbing in the slopes of Dikti mountain, so you get'n by car, bus, motocycle, bicycle. The most well-known paved road climbs up to 900m, and enters from "seli ampelou" at NNW side of plateau. The other paved road, passes from the villages of Mesa and Exo Potamoi, the unpaved roads are known only to the locals
text.head: Get around
text.p: There's a paved ring-road that runs the circumference, and serves the 15 villages, the Mesa Lasithaki served by a junction from Mesa Lasithi, other junctions serving the Diktaio Andron, some facilities, and connecting it with the rest of the island's road network. Because the plateau's economy runs primary on agriculture, an agricultural road network developed for access in the fields, and transporting the loads, recently some of these roads widened & paved making those roads ideal shortcut
text.head: See

list.item: Diktaio Andron (cave of Psichro). The place where Amalthea is said to have nurtured the infant Zeus with her goat's milk. The cave itself is in a lovely location with breath taking views at the top, but small and unexciting. It takes you 15 minutes climbing to get the entrance. However you can hire a donkey at 15€. Don't forget to bring bottled drinking water with you. Entrance ticket: 8€ per person.

text.head: Do
text.p: Depending on the time, there are lots of things to do in Lasithi plateau. But first of all, forget bathing on the beach! Instead, you can participate:

list.item: 1. in the preparations for the potato planting (late April-early June),

text.head: Buy
text.p: Markets (small, medium, and big) do exist in (almost) every village. Except from souvenirs there's nearly nothing else to buy, however because of first sector economy you can buy potatoes (Lasithi Plateau produces around 200,000 tonnes of potatoes), carrots, cucumbers, etc, directly from the producer, and various types of diary products (feta, graviera, kefalotyri, athotyros, tirozouli, the Dikti yogurt) made by the diary (and from the shepherds too) from the milk of sheep and goats.
text.head: Eat
text.p: There are many tavernas and restaurants serving Greek cuisine.
text.head: Drink
text.p: Τhirstiness strikes hard in this area on hot summer days. Fortunately, there are coffee shops and cafes locally. The coffee shops are mostly gathering sites for elderly people and the cafes, for younger ones, because they have billiards tables, betting and coin operated PC's. More English is spoken in the cafes.
Nightlife on the Lasithi Plateau is rare, with only one nightclub open.

text.head: Connect
text.p: Some villages have a free WiFi Hotspot. Some tavernas and cafes also, ask for the code.
2G, 3G, and 4G are also available if you have data plan
text.head: Stay safe
text.p: You will generally be safe if you take normal health and safety precautions for rural areas, with one exception: The greatest danger in this area is falling into open wells. For irrigation, wells are opened, with their depth reaching the 16m, so keep children away and approach with caution.
